nodes.text: Economists' prevailing empirical estimates and integrated assessment models (notably DICE) severely underestimate economic damages from climate change and are therefore unreliable for evaluating climate risk and informing policy

The damage estimates produced by prominent economists (e.g., Nordhaus) report trivial global GDP losses (examples: ~2.1% at 3C and ~7.9% at 6C) which conflict with scientific evidence of major climatic impacts
DICE damage function is quadratic D(DeltaT)=a*DeltaT^2 with a approximately 0.00227 in recent versions, which yields the cited small percentage losses (2.1% at 3C, 7.9% at 6C)
Economists often neglect or misrepresent climate tipping points and tipping cascades, treating them as absent or irrelevant within the century

Scientific literature (Lenton et al. and follow-ups) identifies multiple tipping elements plausibly triggerable this century (e.g., Arctic summer sea-ice, Greenland ice sheet) and tipping cascades that can amplify impacts; Nordhaus mischaracterized or downplayed these findings
A common methodological assumption (enumeration) treats activities not directly exposed to weather as effectively unaffected by climate change, excluding large sectors from damage accounting

Nordhaus 1991 classified roughly 87% of US output (manufacturing, services, government, etc.) as 'negligible effect' from climate because they occur in 'controlled environments', thus largely omitting them from damage estimates

Statistical cross-sectional approaches that use spatial variation in present-day temperature and income as proxies for temporal climate change effects are methodologically flawed and produce misleading extrapolations

Spatial regressions (e.g., US state temperature vs GSP) explain little variance, ignore trade and historical adaptation, and cannot capture novel global-climate changes, extreme wet-bulb heat, or tipping-driven spatial-temporal shifts
IAMs and policy-relevant models (DICE, FUND, PAGE) are calibrated to the same flawed empirical studies and thus inherit their underestimation of damages

DICE couples a Ramsey growth model (representative agent, Cobb-Douglas production, exogenous TFP and labor) with emissions, a quadratic damage function, and convex abatement costs to determine optimal consumption, savings and mitigation paths

Sensitivity analysis of DICE: increasing damage coefficients up to very large values yields model solutions that avoid economic collapse by producing corner solutions (immediate full mitigation), depressed consumption and capital ratios, and eventual recovery; only at extreme damage coefficients (>~98% of GDP) does the solver report infeasibility

Structural model assumptions (Cobb-Douglas production lacking environmental inputs, exogenous TFP and labor, full employment, saddle-path stability and representative-agent optimization) mechanically prevent DICE from generating endogenous economic collapse regardless of damage severity

Given methodological errors, mischaracterization of tipping risks, and structural features that preclude collapse, economists' empirical estimates and IAMs calibrated to them should be rejected as unscientific for evaluating climate risks and for policy formation; science-based approaches must take precedence

Numerical limitation: when damage coefficient is increased beyond a threshold, the DICE solver can fail (infeasible solution), indicating numerical/solution limits but not that the model represents realistic collapse dynamics
